item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: alexandercourt
item.content:encoded:
My Experience
My Portfolio
Contact Me

Click here to view my resumé

Welcome to my personal landing page! Thanks for taking the time to visit and learning a little bit about me.

My name is Alexander Court - I am a driven self-starter with a passion for graphic design. I earned my Bachelor of Commerce degree at the University of Toronto Mississauga, where I majored in economics and specialized in marketing.

My graphic design skills are all entirely self-taught - I take inspiration from everything around me, whether that is social media, TV commercials, print ads, YouTube videos, a design on someone's shirt or graffiti on a wall. I am always looking to expand my skillset, and in my spare time I experiment with different tools and settings in the Adobe Creative Suite to create unique designs and learn new techniques.

item.title: Special Olympics Ontario
item.dc:creator: alexandercourt
item.content:encoded:
In 2018 I had the opportunity to join the Special Olympics Ontario team to support the execution of the Invitational Youth Games - a 4-day world-class sporting event which brought together over 2,000 high school aged athletes with intellectual disabilities from around the world to Toronto. I joined the team as a Web & Graphic Design Coordinator, and in my role I designed not only the event website, but developed the look and feel for all fundraising, social media and print materials promoting the Games. One project I worked on, which remains one of my portfolio items that I am most proud of, was the Commemorative Games Program, a 74-page book given to athletes, coaches, volunteers and spectators of the Games that provides a full list of every coach and athlete that participated in the Games, as well as sponsor recognition, information about the venues, etc. Not only was designing the program an enjoyable experience, but seeing the athletes flipping through the pages and finding their names and even photos of themselves was inspiring and certainly made every hour spent on creating it more than worth it.

Following the Invitational Youth Games, I continued to work with Special Olympics Ontario as the Visual Content & Marketing Officer and later the Manager of Brand & Communications. My involvement spread beyond a single event, and I had the chance to design content and develop communications strategies to encompass all aspects of the organization. I also took on a greater role with the organization's multiple websites, and worked to build out and support the implementation of a donation platform with several large-scale fundraising events. My role has me overseeing the look of feel of anything we distribute to the public, from web to social media and print materials, which are returning to the forefront with special events taking place more often following the pandemic. It's here that my attention to detail really comes into play as I prioritize a unified brand presence for Special Olympics Ontario.

item.title: Virtual Quidditch League
item.dc:creator: alexandercourt
item.content:encoded:
When the COVID-19 pandemic hit and I had more free time, I took the opportunity to learn more and practice new techniques with Adobe Creative Suite. It was also during this time that I learned about online tabletop software which allow users to create board games in a virtual environment. This inspired me to combine my creative passion for design and coming up with games (which stems back to my childhood) with my love of Quidditch and all things Harry Potter.

In June 2020, I co-founded the Virtual Quidditch League (VQL), a small community of (mostly) former Muggle Quidditch (now called Quadball) players and friends. The VQL revolves around a board game based on the rules and positions of the sport from the Wizarding World of Harry Potter, but is played entirely online. For over 2 years, we've built upon the concept, introducing new mechanics and features to the game and developing 16 "seasons" worth of gameplay - with each season having a different theme with an adapted set of rules for the new features. Players play either individually or with a partner and lead a team of characters to score goals, "beat" opposing players (knocking them off their broom) and of course, catching the Golden Snitch. We've structured seasons to give each team 3 preliminary games before the best of the best duke it out in the playoffs, and I've been co-moderating games on an almost nightly basis - with over 400 games to date.

The VQL has truly been a passion project for me, and has allowed me to express my creative ideas in a multitude of ways. I've designed 30 team logos (each one taking a fun spin on an iconic Harry Potter object, character or topic), illustrated 45 magical creatures (including 10 different types of dragons), and came up with 16 different themes for each. Beyond the creative design, I also track team and character stats across each season (so I can tell you how many times fan-favourite Hagrid has fallen off his broom or scored a goal), record every game, and manage a mini-economy, with teams using in-game currency to purchase items to use in games and place bets on the outcomes of games. Each season involves countless hours of development with testing features and designing new mechanics, and I've collaborated closely with another individual who shares the same passion for the sport and game, which has allowed us in turn to improve the VQL through our brainstorming and teamwork sessions. What started as a board game has grown into a small community that reunited a group of people who had grown apart since first meeting in university, while also bringing in some new members along the way!

item.title: UTM Health & Counselling Centre
item.dc:creator: alexandercourt
item.content:encoded:
I first got involved with the University of Toronto Mississauga (UTM) Health & Counselling Centre (HCC) in the second year of my undergrad, where I took on a work-study position as a Communications Assistant. In this role, I worked as part of the Peer Health Education team - a group of student staff with a focus on promoting health and wellness education and resources to students at UTM. My job included managing the HCC's social media channels (including creating graphics and content sharing messages about upcoming health events and educational resources), developing posters for use around campus, and staffing tables and events run by the HCC. It was an fantastic opportunity, and allowed me to connect with other like-minded individuals outside of my program-of-study while also growing my professional skills in marketing and communications.

In the following years at UTM, I continued to work with the HCC but turned my focus to in-person promotions and leadership through the roles of Volunteer Coordinator and then Associate Team Lead, Outreach & Special Events. These jobs expanded my skillsets in working with and managing teams of people, while still leaning into the marketing aspects that I knew I wanted to pursue in my career. These roles saw me working on large scale events focused on health promotion and education which reached thousands of post-secondary students each year.

item.title: UTM Quidditch Team
item.dc:creator: alexandercourt
item.content:encoded:
Back in my first year at the University of Toronto Mississauga, during orientation I heard about the existence of a Quidditch team on campus, and - being a big Harry Potter fan - I knew that I had to find out how I could get involved. The next week I attended one of their info nights, then the first practice, and was instantly hooked on the sport.

Quidditch was one of my few constants across all four years at UTM. I loved the sport, and it brought together a great group of people (a group of people who were not afraid to run around in public with a broom between their legs). After my first year, I got more involved with the team, being elected to Head Coach/Team Captain in second year, before taking on more administrative roles (while still playing the sport) of Vice President - Social and Vice-President - Special Events in my 3rd and 4th years. Given that I was studying marketing, I used this opportunity to grow the team, creating engaging posters and social media content, attracting new members with an array of exciting special events, and even redesigning the team's logo and jerseys.

item.title: Scouts Canada
item.dc:creator: alexandercourt
item.content:encoded:
I joined Scouts Canada way back in 2003 as a Beaver, and grew up in the program, continuing all the way through university and beyond. I've always had an interest in the outdoors, and Scouting gave me the opportunity to try plenty of new activities that I wouldn't have been able to try anywhere else.

My involvement with Scouts Canada also afforded me the chance to grow in a leadership capacity, where I volunteered as an Youth Commissioner for several years and created opportunities for youth development and youth-lead programs across the region. I worked at a summer camp as a counsellor for 2 years before becoming the Program Director, creating several weeks worth of themed summer camp programs for youth ages 8-14. I later went on to volunteer with the National Marketing Team as a Local Marketing Advisor, where I helped other groups to enact recruitment and promotional campaigns, and then worked with the fundraising arm as a Group Specialist supporting Scouters in Calgary in growing their fundraising efforts. After graduating from university I returned to my local Scout Group as a Section Scouter, leading weekly activities and weekend camp and outdoors activities for Cub Scouts (ages 8-11).

item.dc:creator: alexandercourt
item.content:encoded: You can reach me by email at alex.court@live.ca, or by phone at (647) 466-6617. Alternatively, fill out the form below and I will reach out to you - I look forward to talking with you!

item.title: Association of Municipal Managers, Clerks & Treasurers of Ontario (AMCTO)
item.dc:creator: alexandercourt
item.content:encoded:
AMCTO is a professional association serving over 2,200 members from across the province - these members are municipal staff members such as clerks, chief administrative officers (CAOS), finance officers and treasurers, and represent almost all of Ontario's 444 municipalities. I joined AMCTO in February 2023 as Coordinator, Marketing & Communications, and in this role I am responsible for developing marketing materials and collateral for all of the Association's programs and initiatives, including education programs, professional development opportunities and the annual conference.

Early into my time at AMCTO, the Association was undertaking a shift to a new website. This website was built in Drupal, which I became quickly familiar with and worked to update content and design across the entire website. With the new web design, I also worked to update and refresh the Association's brand guidelines and developed tools and resources to support members, staff and other stakeholders in effectively implementing these branding changes.
